articles.headline: Sound of Post-Soviet Protest: Claps and Beeps
articles.snippet: Street politics have lost their relevance in many former Soviet countries, as the political opposition has withered away. But innovative forms of protest are popping up.
articles.abstract: Street politics have lost their relevance in many former Soviet countries, as the political opposition has withered away. But innovative forms of protest are popping up.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — At the time appointed for Wednesday evening’s antigovernment protest here in the capital of Belarus, scores of burly plainclothes officers were waiting in Yakub Kolas Square. Their job was to prevent it from happening.

articles.headline: Google Results Show Growing Strength
articles.snippet: The company’s stock price rose in after-hours trading following the results, which were the first under Larry Page as chief executive.
articles.abstract: The company’s stock price rose in after-hours trading following the results, which were the first under Larry Page as chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In Internet time, Google, founded in 1998, is ancient. But on Thursday, its financial report suggested that it could successfully become more than a search engine and compete in a modern Internet world dominated by sharing real-time information with friends and on mobile phones.

articles.headline: Making Rating Shops Look Good
articles.snippet: When the housing market crumbled, the agencies looked incompetent, conflict-ridden and craven, but as politicians criticize them over sovereign debt, they look noble.
articles.abstract: When the housing market crumbled, the agencies looked incompetent, conflict-ridden and craven, but as politicians criticize them over sovereign debt, they look noble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage securities destroyed the reputations of credit rating agencies. Could sovereign debt restore them?

articles.headline: The Real Winnie the Pooh Returns to the Hundred Acre Wood
articles.snippet: After a decline in merchandise sales, Disney is returning to Winnie the Pooh’s hand-drawn look that was abandoned in 2007 for slick Pixar-style animation.
articles.abstract: After a decline in merchandise sales, Disney is returning to Winnie the Pooh’s hand-drawn look that was abandoned in 2007 for slick Pixar-style animation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s formula for freshening up old cartoon characters like Alvin and the Chipmunks and the Smurfs goes something like this: Reformulate them in 3-D, give them a skateboard and sunglasses, add some dance moves and inundate children and their nostalgic parents with advertising.

articles.headline: Europe Looks for Hope in Bank Test Results
articles.snippet: The European Union hopes that the results of an examination of its financial institutions, to be announced Friday, will quell fears about the banks’ ability to provide loans.
articles.abstract: The European Union hopes that the results of an examination of its financial institutions, to be announced Friday, will quell fears about the banks’ ability to provide loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Plummeting bank stocks. Spreading contagion. Policy makers dazed and confused.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Food Makers Push Back on Ads for Children
articles.snippet: As pressure increases on the food industry to fight childhood obesity, a group of food makers suggested guidelines that are short of nutritional standards proposed by regulators.
articles.abstract: As pressure increases on the food industry to fight childhood obesity, a group of food makers suggested guidelines that are short of nutritional standards proposed by regulators.

articles.headline: Behind Battle Over Debt, a War Over Government
articles.snippet: Intense exchanges over the debt limit have made it clear that it is not so much a budget negotiation as a broader clash between the two parties over the size and role of government.
articles.abstract: Intense exchanges over the debt limit have made it clear that it is not so much a budget negotiation as a broader clash between the two parties over the size and role of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The endgame in the fight to increase the nation’s debt limit has only begun, but intense exchanges this week between the two parties have made it clear that this is not so much a negotiation over dollars and cents as a broader clash between the two parties over the size and role of government.

articles.headline: 2 Top Deputies Resign as Crisis Isolates Murdoch
articles.snippet: Les Hinton, who led Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper subsidiary during the period in which phone hacking occurred, joined Rebekah Brooks in resigning.
articles.abstract: Les Hinton, who led Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper subsidiary during the period in which phone hacking occurred, joined Rebekah Brooks in resigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The crisis rattling Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire claimed the two highest-level executives yet on Friday after days of mounting pressure from politicians and investors on two continents.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Libya Rebels Get Formal Backing, and $30 Billion
articles.snippet: The move gives the rebels access to $30 billion in frozen Libyan assets in the United States and increases pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to resign.
articles.abstract: The move gives the rebels access to $30 billion in frozen Libyan assets in the United States and increases pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The United States formally recognized the rebel leadership in Libya as the country’s legitimate government on Friday, allowing the rebel government access to $30 billion in Libyan assets held in the United States. It is not yet clear how and when the money would be released.
articles.byline: By Sebnem Arsu and Steven Erlanger
